Title: What's going on?
Body: Emotions are connected to your thoughts and beliefs. There is no emotion without a thought. Ask yourself, what am I thinking about that's causing this emotional disturbance? What is the activating event that led to this thought and feeling?
TextPrompt: Ask yourself, what's happenening right now that's triggering you?
VideoName: The Formula For Anger

Title: Where is your 'Should?'
Body: There is no anger without a 'should, must, or demand' statement. The key to unraveling anger, is to find the should belief, and replace it with acceptance. Let's write out what is bothering you and we will then underline all of the 'shoulds'.
TextPrompt: What do you believe should be different about this situation?
VideoName: How We Create Anger And What To Do About It

Title: What is egocentric thinking?
Body: Egocentric Thinking is a way of seeing the world through a lens that says: "Anything I donâ€™t like, find unpleasant, inconvenient, frustrating, or annoying, should not exist. Anything I do like should spring into existence!" It assumes that other people should be putting YOU first. We all have egocentric thinking sometimes, but the worse we have it, the worse we feel (and the worse others feel around us)
TextPrompt: Write down the ways in which you had an egocentric expectation around this situation? What would this situation look like from the other person's perspectice? What might they have been expecting/desiring?
VideoName: Disputing Egocentric Thinking

Title: Let's take acceptance to the next level
Body: The level of peace you feel will always equal the amount that you are accepting/rejecting something. People often talk about letting go, the missing ingredient to actually being able to let go of something is through acceptance.
TextPrompt: What percentage do you honestly feel like you are accepting your should statements? 50%? 60%? Realize that peace comes with 100% acceptance, even of the things we don't like. If you are having a hard time accepting your should, let's say you have 30% acceptance, why not lower? Why not only 10%, or 0%?
VideoName: Learning The Power Of Radical Acceptance

Title: How do we replace 'Should's?'
Body: The key to reframing the beliefs that are causing you harm, is to replace the 'shoulds' with a phrase that does not have any resistance, like it "It would have been better for me if..." the reason this helps is because it accepts that the unwanted outcome did, in fact, happen. This has a significantly difference psychological effect compared to insisting that it "should not have happened'. It did happen, and I would have prefered if [blank] had happened instead.
TextPrompt: Take the shoulds from your previous entry and rewrite those events using the phrase "It would have been better if [blank]"
VideoName: Managing Anger With Shoulds Musts And Demands

Title: Breathe like your life depends on it.
Body: Always remember SOS - self, others, and the situation. Accept your SELF as you are, accept the OTHERS, and accept the SITUATION to the best of your ability.
TextPrompt:
"Remember: Breath is the King of the Mind. If you want to take back control of your mind, it starts by taking control of your breath. 

Nothing to type here, use the video to do the breath exercise. "
VideoName: Meditation Tool The Four Blocks Breath Exercise

Title: Remember to SOS
Body: Always remember SOS - self, others, and the situation. Accept your SELF as you are, accept the OTHERS, and accept the SITUATION to the best of your ability.
TextPrompt:
"Self - In what ways am I rejecting or not accepting aspects of my 'Self'? 
How would it look and feel to forgive and accept yourself fully?
TextPrompt2:
Others - In what ways am I rejecting or not accepting 'Other people or events'?
What are some of the reasons that other people might have done what they did?

Title: Review: Using the ABC's and the Formulas to Feel Better
Body: This animation summarizes what we learned from Dr. Parr about the ABC's, and breaks it down into even simpler terms so that you have full comprehension of how you create and change your emotional state. Use the ABCDE model to fully let go of your current Activating Event.
TextPrompt: Activating Event - What is currently happening that's upsetting you?
VideoName: Animation The ABCs Of Emotions
TextPrompt2: Belief - What beliefs do you have about this activating event?
TextPrompt3: Consequences - How do these beliefs make you feel?
TextPrompt4:
Dispute - Is this belief true? Is it helping you or the situation? |

Effective New Belief - Taking your beliefs from above, what can you replace these irrational beliefs with to make them rational? (e.g "Jonny SHOULD help me clean this mess up." The 'Should' would be replaced with: "It would be better if Jonny helped me clean this mess up")

Title: How are you feeling now?
Body: Think about how you feel now compared to before disputing the formula and breathing. You might feel significantly better, and yet, maybe there's still more. Repeat this process with every block, with every situation bothering you that you can think of, and do these exercises as many days in a row as you can, and you will gradually steer your life into an entirely new upward spiral.
TextPrompt: Notice the connection between beliefs and how you feel. How do you feel after reframing some of those painful beliefs?

Title: What's going on?
Body: There is no emotion without thoughts. Ask yourself, what am I thinking about that's causing this emotional disturbance? What is the activating event that led to this thought?
TextPrompt: Ask youself, what am I thinking about that's causing my worry?
VideoName: How We Create Anxiety And How to Manage It

Title: Let's find your 'What if?'
Body: There is no anxiety without thinking about a 'what if' scenario. This is your brain acting out of self-preservation, it's just trying to keep you safe! We only start to feel stress when we believe in, and dwell on, the what-if scenario. Once we believe it's a fact, we then add then ruminate on how 'awful' it is, until you tell yourself: 'I can't stand it."
TextPrompt: Let's now identify the specific 'What-if' scenarios that you are telling yourself.
VideoName: Anxiety For App Module 1

Title: Disputing the "Awfulizing"
Body: In order to believe it's awful, you must first believe that this made up scenario is also true and inevitable. And then what makes it awful? A fear of judgement, of rejection, of being laughed at or otherwise harmed. The more we accept ourselves fully, and accept what-is, the less these what-if's and hypothetical judgements can affect us.
TextPrompt: Is the what-if scenario actually true? On a scale of 1-100, how awful is it? Why is it not worse?
VideoName: Anxiety For App Module Disputing

Title: Let's dispute the 'I can't stand it' statement
Body: After reading the book, I had a mental breakdown one day. I screamed out loud, " I can't stand it!" and immediately my brain went back to Dr. Parr, wow he was right. This is an example of red-flagging. You may find that there are many aspects of life that are so far away from what you wanted that you simply cannot stand it. When you feel that way, remember that you are currently alive, so you've been able to stand it so far...
TextPrompt: If you were to have exactly what you wanted, what would that look and feel like? In what ways are you different in that scenario? What are some ways that you can become more like that right now?
VideoName: Anxiety For App Module Disputing ICSI

Title: Breathe Like Your Life Depends On It
Body: The 4 Blocks Breath is a breathing technique to help you release negative emotions and physiological sensations. Forcing yourself to breathe deeply will â€˜hackâ€™ your body into feeling calmer. You may find it difficult to breathe deeply at first because your chest is tight and your muscles are constricted, but the deeper you breathe, the more your body will relax. The act of counting the breaths helps the pattern become symettrical and gradually deeper, watch how with the video button on the top right of this card.
TextPrompt: Remember: Breath is the King of the Mind. If you want to take back control of your mind, it starts by taking control of your breath. Nothing to type here, use the video to do the breath exercise.
VideoName: Meditation Tool #3  The Four Blocks Breath Exercise

Title: Remember to SOS
Body: Always remember SOS - self, others, and the situation. Accept your SELF as you are, accept the OTHERS, and accept the SITUATION to the best of your ability.
TextPrompt:
"Self - In what ways am I rejecting or not accepting aspects of my 'Self'? 
How would it look and feel to forgive and accept yourself fully? |

Others - In what ways am I rejecting or not accepting 'Other people or events'?
What are some of the reasons that other people might have done what they did? |

Situation - In what ways am I rejecting or not accepting my 'Situation' (circumstances)
Is complaining about the situatino helping? Is it 100% hopeless? Is there anything that can be done to improve the situation?"

Title: How do you feel now?
Body: Think about how you feel now compared to before disputing and breathing. I'm willing to bet it's significantly better, and yet, maybe there's still more. Repeat this process with every block, with every situation that bothers you that you can think of, and do these exercises as many days in a row as you can, and you will gradually steer your life into an entirely new upward spiral.
TextPrompt: Notice the connection between beliefs and how you feel. How do you feel after reframing some of those painful beliefs?

Title: What's going on?
Body: There is no emotion without thoughts. Ask yourself, what am I thinking about  that's causing this emotional disturbance? What is the activating event that led to this thought?
TextPrompt: Ask yourself, What's happening that triggered you?

Title: Where is your 'Need?'
Body: Depression only happens when we tell ourselves that we "NEED" something in order to be happy. But we don't feel depression if we stop right there, we slowly create the state of depression when we also believe that we are "HELPLESS" and "HOPELESS" to attain that "NEED"
TextPrompt: Let's start by identifying the NEED in your thinking here in this section.

Title: Is it truly hopeless?
Body: Is it true that there you are hopeless? Are there any scenarios in which the need is attainable? What action steps could be taken to move you closer to the need?
TextPrompt: Is it completely 100% true that you are totally hopeless in this situation?

Title: Are you truly helpless
Body:
"Is it true that there you are helpless? Are there any scenarios in which the need is attainable? What action steps could be taken to move you closer to the need?
"
TextPrompt: Is there anything that you can do that would bring close to where you want to be?

Title: Radical Acceptance
Body: There are some cases that the 'need' is truly impossible, in that case we must ask ourselves, do we truly "need" this thing to be happy, or do we merely "want" it really badly? There is a huge emotional difference between "desiring" something, and "demanding" it. Is there anything elsethat could make you happy? Is there a bigger purpose to your life besides this "one thing"?
TextPrompt: Write down some of the other ways that you could feel satisfied or happy.

Title: Breathe like your life depends on it.
Body: The 4 Blocks Breath is a breathing technique to help you release negative emotions and physiological sensations. Forcing yourself to breathe deeply will â€˜hackâ€™ your body into feeling calmer. You may find it difficult to breathe deeply at first because your chest is tight and your muscles are constricted, but the deeper you breathe, the more your body will relax. Title: What's going on?
Body:
"There is no emotion without thoughts.
Ask yourself, what am I thinking about 
that's causing this emotional disturbance?
What is the activating event that led to this
thought?"
TextPrompt: Ask yourself, 'What am I feeling guilty or unworthy about?'
VideoName: How We Create Guilt, And How To Fix It

Title: Unlearning the Formula
Body: Often we believe we are worth less than other people because we've made bad mistakes or have certain flaws that we have decided damage our Self Worth or Personal Value. It is good to feel guilt after you make mistakes, this is the process of learning from your errors so that they do not happen again. It becomes a problem when we get stuck here, and beat ourselves up to no end. The key here is learning your lesson, and then forgiving yourself, and moving forward with a level up.
TextPrompt:
"example:
""I 'should' be successful and in a relationship by now!
Replace the should with:
 ""It would be better"" if I was successful and in a relationship by now.

This is a true statement and offers less cognitive dissonance. You can add additional statements like ""I will make an action plan to become more sucessful and cultivate healthy relationships of all kinds."" But with the should statement replaced, the block can be removed and replaced with beliefs that feel better to you. "
VideoName: Guilt Module 1 For App

Title: Where is your should?
Body:
"There is no guilt without an underlying
belief that you SHOULD be perfect. Now 
that you've done this WRONG thing, you
are now WORTH LESS as a person. This is
BS! Behavior does not equal Self worth,
behavior (aka wrongness or mistakes) are
just behavior, they are not your identity. 
Separate your self worth from your 
perceived imperfections. "
TextPrompt: Why do I think I should feel guilty or unworthy because of my mistakes or flaws? (After your paragraph, go back and put paranthesis around all your 'Should' statemets.)
VideoName: The B.S. Equation For Guilt App

Title: Self Worth is a made up concept!
Body: It's all made up and the points don't matter. Show me your worth and prove it. You can't. Because it is only a belief in our minds that we decide is true even though it hurts us. Do no not cilng to opinions, as if they are facts.
TextPrompt: How would it feel if I threw away the concept of self-worth entirely? How would it feel to completely accept your'self' as you are, even if there is behavior to improve, your 'Self' is already worthy.
VideoName: Disputing Wrongness For Guilt App

Title: How do we replace 'Should's'
Body:
"The solution is incredibly simple:
replace 'should' with 'it would be better.'
This is effective because it is not resisting
that reality is the way it is. When we use a
should statement, we are resisting reality 
which causes cognitive dissonance, which
results in our brains creating stress. Think
about it, ""it should be different."" How could
it be? It's already happened, it can't be 
different from how it is. Accepting reality
will soothe your mind. "
TextPrompt: Rewrite the 'shoulds' from your previous entry. Write a new paragrarph replacing the 'should' statements with the phrase 'It would be better
VideoName: Shoulds In Relation To Guilt For App

Title: Breathe Like Your Life Depends On it

"The 4 Blocks Breath is a breathing technique to help you release negative emotions and physiological sensations. Forcing yourself to breathe deeply will â€˜hackâ€™ your body into feeling calmer. You may find it difficult to breathe deeply at first because your chest is tight and your muscles are constricted, but the deeper you breathe, the more your body will relax. The act of counting the breaths helps the pattern become symettrical and gradually deeper, watch how with the video button on the top right of this card. 

Remember: Breath is the King of the Mind. If you want to take back control of your mind, it starts by taking control of your breath. 

"

Title: Intro to the Disputer Tool
Body: In this course, Dr. Vincent E. Parr, a clinical psychologist and recognized leader in Rational Theory, will teach you to master the negative emotions that block your happiness. He provides groundbreaking, easy-to-follow explanations, formulas, tools, and examples to manage the four blocks to happiness: Anger, Anxiety, Depression and Guilt.
TextPrompt: On a scale of 1 to 10, how ready are you to let go of beilefs that are causing you suffering? What number did you choose? Why did you not choose a lower number?
VideoName: What You Are About To Learn

Title: The 3 Insights to a Mind of Peace
Body: There are three basic insights into the human condition that help us become more aware of how we upset ourselves. These insights are the fundamental building blocks to a rational mind. Without these insights, it's practically impossible for you to be happy or content in your lifetime.
TextPrompt: Watch the video to continue.
VideoName: The Three Insights To Happiness

Title: The ABC's of Emotions
Body: In this video, Dr. Parr goes deeper into the second insight, which is the knowledge of how you create your emotions, both good and bad!
TextPrompt: Watch this video and then come back and write down some activating events that you believe are triggering you!
VideoName: Animation The ABCs Of Emotions

Title: The 7 Irrational Beliefs Behind All Suffering
Body: It's impossible to become disturbed without thinking these 7 irrational beliefs. Learning how to find these beliefs and dispute them is a major key to getting better from anger, anxiety, guilt and depression.
TextPrompt: Watch the video and then come back and write down some irrational beliefs that you think you may be saying often!
VideoName: The 7 Irrational Beliefs Behind All Suffering

Title: Mental Contamination
Body: It's impossible to get better from anger, anxiety, guilt and depression without first letting go of mental contamination.
TextPrompt: A lot of emotional pain is caused by mistaking opinions for facts. Most of the stuff in our heads is BS. What are some stories in your head that are causing you pain?
VideoName: Mental Contamination

Title: The Importance of Meditation
Body: Dr. Parr says, "the most difficult part of helping people recover, is convincing them to meditate." Meditation is the difference between learning something, and embodying it. It's the art of training the mind for peace and clarity.
TextPrompt: Use the videos in this module to master your meditation skills and watch how your mind and mood improves.
VideoName: The Importance of Meditation

Title: Remember to SOS
Body: Always remember SOS - self, others, and the situation. Accept your SELF as you are, accept the OTHERS, and accept the SITUATION to the best of your ability.
TextPrompt:
